I've had that thought from around 30 years ago about infrared light.
As an inventor type, I'm inspired by learning about effects, reactions and putting them together in novel ways to achieve new things. For example, I've been sitting on a heat to electricity surface conversion process since my late teens that is likely quite close to feasible construction though only in the modern chip fab facilities. Those of us who are inventors with some degree of abstract thought for example, can conceptualize the requirement for thermal stratification in a heat exchanger to counteract the short circuit otherwise developed from use of low thermal conductivity materials. However, it's not the same as working in a dark room and knowing you have cut off all the visible light or of putting a draft stop at the bottom of a closed door because of feeling cold air on your feet. Our inventions are constrained by our environment and our shuttered perception of it. We are very lucky to be able to conceptualize past this into that we don't feel or see. It's one of those go/no go thresholds I think about for space aliens on other worlds and for other species on our own planet that permits development of novel industrialization.

For a long time I always wondered why I was near blind during day, and especially during summer.
Doctors thought my eyes were photophobic, so I used normal sunglasses without UV protection, but everything was still hazy, I thought it were the glasses from the sunglasses.

Few years later I went to the doctor again and they did further tests, I was suppose to look at different lights in the colour spectrum, only to be able to see the UV lights as their true colour.
Since then I always wear glasses during day that block majority of UV light so I can properly see during day.

It's always weird being able to see colours most people can't.
Where I am able to see a certain colour.
Most people either see bright pink or dark blue, some even see just greyish black.
I do have a massive advantage at night, where I see near clear without extra lights, other people always need extra lights to see normal.

Also the sky for me is more UV coloured than blue.

Okay, so my theory is that because light is a stream of particles and not a true wave, the particles the UV sources emit are different in a way that means more things absorb them, and hence less reflect them.

Derek mentioned early on that the energy per photon is higher, but the wavelength is shorter, so I that makes sense with less shades of grey. It's closer to a binary thing, they're either mostly absorbed or mostly reflected, whereas in ROYGBIV it's a mor obvious continuum.

So, my theory is that in the UV range, we see more like dogs do - with more distinction, but really bad noise filtering - we get washed out lots, but in low light, we see amazing detail and probably long distances too, because if the photons don't interact with anything else, they hit our retina with lots of energy, and hence leave a bit impression. But it's a trade off, so lots of intensity means a narrower spectrum, because the energy either makes more wavelengths (colours), or more... idk, force?

Whilst putting on sunscreen is good, we also have a lot of people with vitamin D deficiencies caused by.. being indoors a lot more than before AND putting on more sunscreen.
So.. use sunscreen for those really harsh sun-shocks, but remember to enjoy the sun once in a while and take supplements in winter.

What UV filter and camera did you use for this? I've been researching UV-passing filters transmission spectra and they all have the problem of allowing in near-IR light. And I've also researched IR blocking filters, which all seem to also have unwanted characteristics such as also blocking UV light (basically being visible light passing filter), or else they didn't have a strong enough blocking of the near-IR light. So I hope you tell me what filters you used with your camera, and also whether you were using a full spectrum modified camera like me, or if you were using a dedicated scientific UV camera (one with the CCD sensor itself designed and optimized for increased sensitivity in the UV spectrum, and less sensitive than a normal camera to light outside the UV spectrum).

When I was in school for Dental Technology (1990), a classmate was puzzled as to why he could not meet girls in nightclubs or bars, but had no issues in other settings.  As we were in the lab testing dental ceramics used for crowns to see which ceramic products fluoresced light blue like natural teeth; when the UV light was turned on I discovered why he had trouble meeting girls in clubs.  He had broken his two upper front teeth playing on the monkey bars as a child and when he was 18, had permanent crowns installed.  Some of the older dental ceramics had used feldspars that fluoresced bright 'slime' green, which  his two front crowns did.  Our next years project was to make him new crowns that fluoresced light blue like natural teeth.  Then his social night life where they had black lights, instantly improved, to his delight!

At 1:33 - the 'haze' with a UV camera is a great demonstration of why the sky is blue. It's showing that the UV light refracts more than the lower frequencies, and since the blue/violet spectrum of visible light is the highest frequencies, they scatter more. A UV camera isn't picking up those lower frequencies, so it can't see anything through the 'haze'. :)

This is a very helpful video about a subject i have so many questions about. I came across an old study on line a while back done by the bureau of weights and measures in a 1932 publication of theirs. It was highly sophisticated for the time and included all the data they collected. I think the title was " an investigation into the measuring of extreme ultraviolet solar radiation to reach the planets surface. In the report they claim that one day smoke from a nearby forest fire had drifted over their measuring instruments and that the extreme u/v more then doubled in intensity.  They at first were baffled but later discovered what had happened was that instead of the occasional ray to reach the surface of the planet the smoke allowed the extream portion of the u/v to i think the word used was defuse but i am probably wrong .it allowed the u/v to scatter which made the whole sky become the source of U/v instead of the ray . Later i thought it must be the same phenomenon that allows people to get sun burned in the fog. So if this is correct would the intentional blocking of sunlight by scientist by injecting especially water vapor  into the atmosphere actually harmful to living organisms?  They do this often in California and i have plenty of evidence that they do. One more thing that your video touched upon was the u/v and the flowers. Its always a fun reminder that, the way we see the world, is not how the world actually "looks like", but rather we just so happened to evolve and develop these things we call eyes that so happen to sense the visible light spectrum and then our brain creates the experience of sight. Its also fun to remember that, colors don't actually exist in the external world, apples don't have red color, our brains simply create the experience of red based on the wavelength of light that is not absorbed by various objects. We often forget that visible light is electromagnetic radiation, the same thing as microwaves, radio-waves, UV etc... In reality, the world does not exist without our senses & brain to create the experience of the world. "reality" is essentially a very very popular hallucination.

Did you know that many cameras have a filter placed, by the factory, in front of the film plane ,or CMOS plane to remove ultraviolet and Infrared light from the picture so that the picture looks the way viewers expect the world to look. When you have these filters removed.you have an 'All spectrum Camera'. There are things you will see that are just incredible. It's like night vision, you look through night vision equipment there is no doubt that what you are seeing is real. What ever you see with night vision would surely be there even if you didn't have the camera. Now, much of the stuff seen with UV and IR equipment is beyond weird. Cartoonist figures in the clouds. Foliage in particular at night near the bank of a meandering brook. Cars that appear in physical light to be doing car stuff like parking or driving; meanwhile in the UV range parts of them are folding up, in impossible ways.... They are re configuring into flying machines. Turn your back for a second and they are gone. Then focus on the Cessna 172 above you. It sounds like a Cessna, looks like a Cessna plane So you zoom out and manage to catch it in the middle of the frame and what do you have ? A small ball of plasma is all that was seen by your special camera. Yes, there are enough phenomena that I think it's clear that the Aliens are here and that there are all sort of new technologies In use. Both IR and UV are used in automatic guiding and landing systems.. In past centuries a camouflaged flyer would have been guarded by 'the elves' the people of the forest, by the trees themselves. The parking area would be avoided as an evil spot with restless spirits. The vehicle operator ,could have just as easily been a member of the upper classes or humanoid alien. He would leave his 3 story Estate house and would be merely making his daily morning walk through the woods that he always took to get to the village. Approaching a certain spot, he pressed a button on his black pipe as white smoke lazily spiraled out..Noiselessly but faster than it takes to say it, the covering of dead leaves and small logs and stones moved off like a matt, uncovering a device of the blackest black. It rose to a 30 degree angle off the forest floor. . Colored lights began to rotate faster and faster silently underneath it. He heard a loud sound behind him ...and with the beginnings of a smile jumped smartly right into the center depression, one of 4. In that second going invisible he leaned forward to coach more speed out of his platform, silently vanishing heading west, using the roman wall as his guide. - Travelin2wit

I can see UVA with my human eyes.  Because of cataracts, my human lenses have been with replaced with acrylic lenses that pass most of the UVA spectrum.  The "color" of UVA is blue.  The only reason we see violet at 400 nm  is that our red cones respond to this "harmonic" of red light.  Disadvantage of acrylic lenses is they are fixed focus.  So I wear trifocals to focus at infinity, 0.6 m and 0.3 m.  Close enough.  I First noticed this at Disneyland when only one cataract had been replaced with an acrylic lens and that eye could see the UV light on a ride and the eye still with a cataract could not see the UV light.

You know what, I've wondered why we couldn't evolve to see in the ultraviolet. I mean, you would think that those with vision of a larger portion of the electromagnetic spectrum would be better off, and yet we have a very specific and narrow band of vision. Now that I've seen what the sky looks like in UV, I realize what a huge detriment that would be to our survival. Our vision is just narrow enough to give us the clearest possible view. If we could see all of the UV wavelengths our ability to see farther off would be significantly reduced no? Infrared would be just as problematic, so much black body radiation clogging things up as it were. Insects on the other hand are much more interested on the up close and personal, hence vision in UV wouldn't be as detrimental to their everyday lives.

No, if you could see ultraviolet, you still wouldn't say "why is the sky ultraviolet", you'd still say "why is the sky blue". Because the color you would call blue, would be MY ultraviolet. You simply would have different thresholds for what you see and the English words would stand for different frequencies. The point is that higher frequencies are scattered more than lower ones, so any being with any color range would see a blue sky, whatever that range is, because the higher frequencies that they can see, would be scattered more than the lower ones.

It's not a very accurate representation of UV. Just like the Visible Spectrum, the Ultraviolet Spectrum also has its own "rainbow". UVA being the "red" side, UVB being like "green" since it's in the middle, and UVC being "blue". Thus, since UVC is completely absorbed by the Ozone Layer, UVB is mostly, and UVA isn't, the "fog" seen on the UV camera should be roughly orange-ish. That camera only shows the intensity of the UV, but not the Wavelength/Frequency.

I think a great follow-up to this video would be on exploring why scientists think our visible spectrum is so narrow among the electromagnetic spectrum. I imagine that it is a combination of the range limitations of photoreceptors and the utility of seeing in that range for the tasks mammals need to survive. If the range was too far in the UV the air would be even more hazy making it difficult to hung game in the distance. If the vision was too far in the infrared direction then we may miss some potentially dangerous obstacles because they would be transparent.

Dude this is so interesting. My theory as to why the landscape shot looked hazy had to do with the whole idea that light, the further it travels, the dimmer it gets. Basically since the UV light is a shorter wavelength (thinking in terms of the classic wavelength diagram of a modifiable sine wave) in order to travel the same distance the uv light has to "work more," "use more ink" (if we think of drawing the diagram with a pen), as compared to visible light. Because of this i thought it would dim over a shorter distance causing that hazy effect. That is the best way i can think of to explain it.

That haze explains why the UV Index drops off so quickly later in the day.  On a clear late afternoon with the hot sun on your skin (infra-red,) it becomes more and more "UV-overcast."  As the sun's light heads through a thicker layer of atmosphere due to the  steeper angles, much less of the UV ultimately makes it to your skin.  The infra-red may feel 90% of what it did at noon, but the UV will only be around 30% of what it was at noon.

Your video is good as far as it goes. It might be far more interesting if, instead of translating the detected UV into a single visible wavelength for "black and white" viewing, you translated the UV wavelengths into a proportional visible wavelength for "full color" viewing.

There must be a camera image sensor that can to this. As far as image sensors go, there's nothing special in nature that limits color sensors to be responsive ONLY to visible wavelengths. It must be possible to do the same in the UV part of the spectrum (and IR for that matter).

For example, capture images in the UV spectrum, and simply double the wavelengths through image processing. Or triple the captured wavelengths. Better yet, capture a much wider part of the UV spectrum, and scale the wavelengths down to fit in the visible spectrum. This would promise to provide insights deeper into the UV spectrum. The sky is blue because air is blue. Blue light bounces off it and hits our eyes. Same as why anything is any colour. It's not because of scattering. You're just seeing more or the air. Rayleigh scattering isn't necessary to explain it, at all. :|

This is kind of a dorky thing to mention, but kind of relevant to the final points made in the video... Get a digital camera, your phone with a camera, whatever.. and a remote control for a TV or something that uses infrared to give its signals. Now look at smooth plastic panel where the IR light comes out of and press some buttons.. can't see anything. Now point your camera at the remote, and look at it through the camera's screen, instead of your naked eye. Now you can see the lights flashing from the end of the remote.

Now sure, a lot of people know that... but what made this more mind-blowing for me, is when I put the end of the remote near something so that when I press the buttons the lights shine on that surface.. That's what made the light more 'real' for me. The fact that there's light being cast on another object right in front of me, but it would look completely dark to my naked eye.. but my camera can see the source and the cast light just fine.

Think of all the light you can't see, and all the radio waves passing through you at every moment, and near-light-speed, super-tiny particles that literally go through your body as if it wasn't even there all the time.. It's interesting, to me, to stop and think about that kind of stuff.

My understanding of the sky's color was that Raleigh scattering makes the sky bluer, which would be a much deeper, but still bright, blue; but the sun's emmission spectrum emits more yellow-green light, and multiplying those two functions creates a peak at the wavelength between cyan and true blue, which becomes known as sky blue.
Thus, the sky's color doesn't depend nearly so much on what our eyes see as the product of the scattering and emission curves, and the sky would not be an ultraviolet color, if we could see such colors.

You don't need an ultraviolet camera in order to see what the world might look like in ultraviolet. Here is a comparison photo of Derek in Color and Blue light. https://i.imgur.com/UdsCTpK.jpg Take any color photograph and load it up in a photo editor like photoshop. Go to the channels area where Red, Green, and Blue are separated by the software. Turn off the red and green channels. What you're left with is a black and white photo comprised only of blue (violet) light, which is the closest to ultraviolet that our eyes can see. The world looks very different in blue light and very similar to ultraviolet light. You will see freckles even on fair skinned people, false teeth look different, flowers look different.

For the people wondering: "Why aren't we all black if UV is just harmful?"
The reason is vitamin D. You NEED sunlight to make this vitamin and you need this vitamin to be healthy.
If you have enough sunlight (like around the equator) you easily get enough vitamin D even through the blackest skin.
A population living in areas with less sunlight will gradually lose a lot of its melanin to maximize the vitamin D synthesis and because there is not that much sun and therefore not that much of a risk of skin cancer.
(Edit: I thought it was vitamin K, it's D apparently)

Interesting. In the point of view of 3D artist like me. I simulate light. People skin is one of thing that most complicate to replicate and worth hours to study to understanding the principal, and we take a lot of time comparing it to photo, diagnosis the error that make it look not right compare to actual skin. And through years of doing that, It's interesting that what I see in the image of human skin in UV is look similar to when we do the epidermal pass. That less of roughness (more reflective, instead of randomly scatter). And what's missing (or less visible) is subdermal pass that need more complicated light path called sub-surface scattering. That's not just that it reflect randomly like any ligt hit on roughly surface (like cloth), But more like marble, candle or translucent rasin. Light penetrate deep into the surface, Got scatter inside like you shine flashligt into foggy atmosphere, then the light goes back in other direction. For human skin, this is would commonly represent artistically as more red than epidermal pass. And here, Thinking about what really happen here in the UV filter image. It filtering out those less frequentcy wavelength. While UV is super short. That means, UV would be more likely to reflect off your skin or go through it. But not much scattering, especially when compare to longer wavelength visible light.

It's amazing to see those two side by side. What your seeing is the difference between Rayleigh and Mie scattering. Rayleigh is particle based scattering, on it's own it only accounts for the color of the sky and the appearance of sunlight on surfaces. Mie scattering is wavelength interference created by gas concentrations in the air, essentially fog but occurs differently for different wavelengths depending on medium.

The reason the tonic water looks black outside is that if you look at the physics, the source function is less than the background intensity. It's why you see absorption in the Sun. The sun still emits the radiation, but it emits the radiation with a smaller source function than the background continuum intensity that was absorbed. It's why projectors make black by not producing light. Your eye perceives the contrast of intensity as dark/black.

From photography (or videography) stand point, a UV image (or video) basically considered as "false color image (or video)".
Basically human eyes "only" capable of "interpreting" light in a very limited wavelength, hence a UV light bouncing off a surface of "something colored" would produce a color that we human never see with our natural eyes (if we can see it), imagine seeing a brand new color that you can not name it.
Similar things actually happened on the other end of visible light spectrum, the IR (infrared).

some optical sensor (or specifically modified one) and lenses will be able to capture these "invisible light energy/photons" bouncing off things and interpret it as electrons value; those values will then be converted in to different electricity energy for "luminosity" information, ie. how bright (or dark) things are captured by those pixel.

Here we can ponder, why luminosity?
well, cause it is, those monochrome images/videos is just luminosity information of UV/IR energy bounced off things to be interpreted by the sensor for human eye to see, otherwise we can't see anything in UV/infrared; sometimes they do try to process color to it by adding colored filters, however that's not the "real color" (in sense of normal human understanding of color) reflected off things by those UV/IR light, hence the term "false color photography/videography".
